p.s: I am writing to you in response to the interview of Ayad Akhtar in Guernica Magazine.
We have recently read Disgraced in school and I have found it very interesting, esspeciallyespecially Ayad Akhtar's views of faith and identity, as he talked about in your interview.
Even toughthough I don't know, what it is like beeingbeing a minority, I still think I understand what Ayad Akhtar wants to express in that part of the interview.
I would have to disagree with him, as I think your identity marker is not given from outside, you can change it.
I also think, that identity is not reliant on faith or even ethnicity.
Your identity is what interest you, what you like or dislike and your opinions as well as other factors.
It is not neccesarillynecessarily dependent on your background, if you don't want to.
Your identity is also not, what people think of you, when they first see you, but it is what people think of you, who have known you for a long time.
This can also be seen in the character of Amir in Disgraced.
He changes his identity away from islam and his upbringing.
I hope this letter has informed you on a new view of identity.
